original.title: Book VI: The Philosopher's Nature
original.preview: Socrates: And thus, Glaucon, after the argument has gone a weary way, the true and the false philosophers have at length appeared in view.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And thus, Glaucon, after the argument has gone a weary way, the true and the false philosophers have at length appeared in view.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I do not think that the way could have been shortened.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I suppose not. And yet I believe that we might have had a better view of both of them if the discussion could have been confined to this one subject.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And what is the next question?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Surely the one which follows next in order. Inasmuch as philosophers only are able to grasp the eternal and unchangeable, and those who wander in the region of the many and variable are not philosophers, I must ask you which of the two classes should be the rulers of our State?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And how can we rightly answer that question?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whichever of the two are best able to guard the laws and institutions of our State—let them be our guardians.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Neither can there be any question that the guardian who is to keep anything should have eyes rather than no eyes?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There can be no question of that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And are not those who are verily and indeed wanting in the knowledge of the true being of each thing, and who have in their souls no clear pattern, simply blind?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Truly, they are much in that condition.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the first place, as we began by observing, the nature of the philosopher has to be ascertained.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let us suppose that philosophical minds always love knowledge of a sort which shows them the eternal nature not varying from generation and corruption.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Agreed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And further, let us agree that they are lovers of all true being; there is no part whether greater or less, or more or less honourable, which they are willing to renounce.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if they are to be what we were describing, is there not another quality which they should also possess?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What quality?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Truthfulness: they will never intentionally receive into their mind falsehood, which is their detestation, and they will love the truth.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, that may be safely affirmed of them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is there anything more akin to wisdom than truth?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How can there be?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can the same nature be a lover of wisdom and a lover of falsehood?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Never.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: He whose desires are drawn towards knowledge in every form will be absorbed in the pleasures of the soul, and will hardly feel bodily pleasure—I mean, if he be a true philosopher and not a sham one.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That is most certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such an one is sure to be temperate and the reverse of covetous; for the motives which make another man desirous of having and spending, have no place in his character.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then how can he who has magnificence of mind and is the spectator of all time and all existence, think much of human life?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He cannot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Or can such an one account death fearful?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No indeed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the cowardly and mean nature has no part in true philosophy?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly not.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: To these statements, Socrates, no one can offer a reply; but when you talk in this way, a strange feeling passes over the minds of your hearers.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They fancy that they are led astray a little at each step in the argument, and at the end of the discussion they are found to have sustained a mighty overthrow and all their former notions appear to be turned upside down.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: For any one of us might say that although in words he is not able to meet you at each step of the argument, he sees as a fact that the votaries of philosophy, when they carry on the study as the pursuit of their maturer years, most of them become strange monsters, not to say utter rogues.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, and do you think that those who say so are wrong?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I cannot tell; but I should like to know what is your opinion.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Hear my answer; I am of opinion that they are quite right.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Then how can you be justified in saying that cities will not cease from evil until philosophers rule in them, when philosophers are acknowledged by us to be of no use to them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You ask a question to which a reply can only be given in a parable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Imagine then a fleet or a ship in which there is a captain who is taller and stronger than any of the crew, but he is a little deaf and has a similar infirmity in sight, and his knowledge of navigation is not much better.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The sailors are quarrelling with one another about the steering—every one is of opinion that he has a right to steer, though he has never learned the art of navigation.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They throng about the captain, begging and praying him to commit the helm to them; and if at any time they do not prevail, but others are preferred to them, they kill the others or throw them overboard.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Having first chained up the noble captain's senses with drink or some narcotic drug, they mutiny and take possession of the ship and make free with the stores.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Him who is their partisan and cleverly aids them in their plot, they compliment with the name of sailor, pilot, able seaman, and abuse the other sort of man, whom they call a good-for-nothing.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But that the true pilot must pay attention to the year and seasons and sky and stars and winds, and whatever else belongs to his art, if he intends to be really qualified for the command of a ship—the possibility of this has never seriously entered into their thoughts.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now in vessels which are in a state of mutiny, how will the true pilot be regarded? Will he not be called by them a prater, a star-gazer, a good-for-nothing?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then you will hardly need to hear the interpretation of the figure, which describes the true philosopher in his relation to the State.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Say to him, that, in deeming the best votaries of philosophy to be useless to the rest of the world, he is right; but also tell him to attribute their uselessness to the fault of those who will not use them, and not to themselves.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The pilot should not humbly beg the sailors to be commanded by him—that is not the order of nature.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Precisely so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And may we not say, Adeimantus, that the most gifted minds, when they are ill-educated, become pre-eminently bad? Do not great crimes and the spirit of pure evil spring out of a fulness of nature ruined by education rather than from any inferiority?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: There I think that you are right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And our philosopher follows the same analogy—he is like a plant which, having proper nurture, must necessarily grow and mature into all virtue, but, if sown and planted in an alien soil, becomes the most noxious of all weeds.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Do you really think, as people so often say, that our youth are corrupted by Sophists? Are not the public who say these things the greatest of all Sophists?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And do they not educate to perfection young and old, men and women alike, and fashion them after their own hearts?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: When is this accomplished?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When they meet together, and the world sits down at an assembly, or in a court of law, or a theatre, and there is a great uproar, and they praise some things which are being said or done, and blame other things, equally exaggerating both, shouting and clapping their hands.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: At such a time will not a young man's heart leap within him? Will any private training enable him to stand firm against the overwhelming flood of popular opinion?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, Socrates; necessity will compel him.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And yet there is a still greater necessity, which has not been mentioned.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What is that?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The gentle force of attainder or confiscation or death which, as you are aware, these new Sophists and educators who are the public, apply when their words are powerless.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Indeed they do; and in right good earnest.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, Adeimantus, the worthy disciples of philosophy will be but a small remnant.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those who belong to this small class have tasted how sweet and blessed a possession philosophy is, and have also seen enough of the madness of the multitude.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They know that no politician is honest, nor is there any champion of justice at whose side they may fight and be saved.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Such an one may be compared to a man who has fallen among wild beasts—he will not join in the wickedness of his fellows, but neither is he able singly to resist all their fierce natures.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, and he will have done a great work before he departs.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A great work—yes; but not the greatest, unless he find a State suitable to him; for in a State which is suitable to him, he will have a larger growth and be the saviour of his country, as well as of himself.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I should like to know which of the governments now existing is in your opinion the one adapted to philosophy.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Not any of them; and that is precisely the accusation which I bring against them—not one of them is worthy of the philosophic nature.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What is there remaining?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The question how the study of philosophy may be so ordered as not to be the ruin of the State: All great attempts are attended with risk; 'hard is the good,' as men say.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Still, let the point be cleared up.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: At present, the students of philosophy are quite young; beginning when they are hardly past childhood, they devote only the time saved from moneymaking and housekeeping to such pursuits.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And even those of them who are reputed to have most of the philosophic spirit, when they come within sight of the great difficulty of the subject, I mean dialectic, take themselves off.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What do you propose?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Quite the from of the present practice. In childhood and youth their study, and what philosophy they learn, should be suited to their tender years.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And as life advances, when the soul begins to reach maturity, let them increase the gymnastics of the soul; but when the strength of our citizens fails and is past civil and military duties, then let them range at will and engage in no serious labour.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: How earnest you are, Socrates! I am sure of that; and yet most of your hearers, if I am not mistaken, are likely to be still more earnest in their opposition to you.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Do not make a quarrel between Thrasymachus and me, who have recently become friends, although, indeed, we were never enemies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For we shall go on striving to the utmost until either we convince him and others, or at least do something that may profit them against the day when they live again and hold the like discourse in another state of existence.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You are speaking of a myth which is yet to come!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Nay, rather of a time which is now and not yet to come.

modern.title: Book VI: What Makes a Philosopher
modern.preview: Socrates: So Glaucon, after this long journey, we've finally distinguished true philosophers from fake ones.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So Glaucon, after this long journey, we've finally distinguished true philosophers from fake ones.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I don't think we could have taken a shortcut.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Probably not. Though it would've been clearer if we'd focused just on this topic.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What's next?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The obvious question. Since only philosophers can grasp eternal, unchanging truths, and everyone else is lost in the world of constantly changing appearances—which group should rule our state?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: How do we decide that?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whichever group can best protect our laws and institutions—they should be our guardians.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And obviously, a guardian who's supposed to watch over something should have eyes, right?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Obviously.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So people who don't really know the true nature of things, who have no clear vision of reality in their minds—aren't they basically blind?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, pretty much.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First, we need to understand what a philosopher's nature actually is.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's say philosophical minds love the kind of knowledge that reveals eternal truths—things that don't change or decay.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Agreed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And they love all of truth—they won't give up any part of it, big or small.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is there another quality they need?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What quality?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Honesty. They'll never accept falsehood into their minds—they hate lies and love truth.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yeah, that's definitely true of them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is anything more connected to wisdom than truth?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Nothing.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Can someone love wisdom and love lies at the same time?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Never.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Someone whose desires are drawn toward knowledge will be absorbed in intellectual pleasures and barely notice physical ones—if they're a real philosopher, not a fake.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They'll naturally be moderate and not greedy. The things that make other people obsessed with money just don't matter to them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If someone's mind can contemplate all of time and existence, how much can they really care about this short human life?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Not much.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And would they be afraid of death?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No way.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So cowardly, petty people can't be real philosophers?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Definitely not.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Socrates, nobody can argue with what you're saying. But something weird happens when you talk like this—listeners feel like they're being led astray step by step, and by the end, everything they believed has been turned upside down.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Even though they can't argue with you, anyone can see that people who pursue philosophy into adulthood mostly become weird outcasts—or worse, total scoundrels.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Do you think they're wrong about that?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I don't know. What do you think?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I think they're completely right.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Then how can you say cities won't be free from problems until philosophers rule, when you admit philosophers are useless?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I can only answer that with a story.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Imagine a ship where the captain is bigger and stronger than the crew, but he's a bit deaf and blind, and doesn't really know navigation.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The sailors are all fighting over who gets to steer—each one thinks he should, even though none of them ever learned how to navigate.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They crowd around the captain, begging for the wheel. When they don't get it, they throw the competition overboard or kill them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They drug the captain, take over the ship, and raid the supplies.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Anyone who helps them take control, they call a 'real sailor.' Anyone else is a 'useless dreamer.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But the idea that a true pilot needs to study the stars, weather, and seasons—that's never even occurred to them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: On a ship run by mutineers, what would they call the real navigator? A 'stargazer' and 'useless dreamer,' right?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You probably don't need me to explain that this describes the philosopher's relationship to the state.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yeah, I get it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Tell people who think philosophers are useless that they're right—but it's not the philosophers' fault. It's the fault of people who won't use them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A real captain shouldn't have to beg sailors to let him navigate. That's not how it works.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Exactly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's the thing, Adeimantus: the most gifted people, when poorly educated, become the worst. Great evil comes from corrupted potential, not from weakness.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I think you're right about that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A philosopher is like a plant. With proper care, it grows into something beautiful. But planted in the wrong soil, it becomes the worst kind of weed.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Do you really think Sophists corrupt young people? Isn't the public itself the biggest Sophist of all?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Doesn't the public educate everyone—young and old, men and women—and shape them into its own image?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: When does that happen?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When crowds gather—in assemblies, courts, theaters—and there's this huge uproar. They cheer some things and boo others, way over the top, shouting and clapping.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What young person can resist that flood of popular opinion? What private education can stand against it?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You're right—they can't resist.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And there's an even stronger force.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What's that?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: When words fail, the public uses force—imprisonment, property seizure, death. The mob is the ultimate Sophist.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They definitely do that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So true philosophers will always be a tiny minority.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those few have tasted how sweet philosophy is, and they've seen how crazy the masses are.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They know no politician is honest, and there's no champion of justice they can fight alongside.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It's like falling in with wild animals—you won't join their evil, but you can't fight them all alone either.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: At least they'll accomplish something before they die.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Something, yes. But not the greatest thing—not unless they find a state that suits them. In the right state, they could truly flourish and save their country.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Which existing government do you think is suited to philosophy?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: None of them. That's exactly my complaint—no current government is worthy of a philosophical nature.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: So what's left to figure out?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: How to organize the study of philosophy so it doesn't ruin the state. All great projects carry risk. As they say, 'good things are hard.'

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Let's work that out.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Right now, philosophy students are too young. They squeeze in some studying between making money and managing households.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Even the most philosophical ones quit when they hit the really hard stuff—dialectic. They just give up.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What would you change?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Flip the current system. In childhood and youth, give them philosophy suited to their age.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: As they mature, intensify the mental training. When they're past the age for military and civic duties, let them devote themselves fully to philosophy.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You're really serious about this, Socrates! But I think most people hearing you will resist even harder.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Don't start a fight between me and Thrasymachus—we just became friends! We were never really enemies anyway.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We'll keep trying until we convince them, or at least help them for when they come back in another life and have this conversation again.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You're talking about some future myth!

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: No—I'm talking about right now.
